message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history, physical examination and cardiac auscultation suggest an atrial septal defect. This defect often presents with exertional dyspnea and a systolic ejection murmur, as well as a mid-diastolic rumble along the left sternal border. Bicuspid aortic valve may have a systolic murmur but not a diastolic rumble. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may present with dyspnea but typically has a harsh systolic murmur. Ventricular septal defect would cause a holosystolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of mild exertional dyspnea, and the physical examination reveals a grade II systolic ejection murmur along the left upper sternal border and a mid-diastolic rumble along the left sternal border. These are characteristic findings of an atrial septal defect. Bicuspid aortic valve would present with systolic ejection click and mid-systolic murmur. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy would present with a harsh systolic murmur, and Ventricular septal defect would present with a harsh holosystolic murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a murmur along the left upper sternal border and a mid-diastolic rumble along the left sternal border, which are indicative of an atrial septal defect. The other options do not present with these specific findings. The patient's history of immigration and unknown vaccination history may also contribute to the possibility of infectious diseases such as tuberculosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history and physical exam suggest a cardiac defect. The grade II systolic ejection murmur along the left upper sternal border and a mid-diastolic rumble along the left sternal border are consistent with an atrial septal defect. Bicuspid aortic valve is associated with an early systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy typically presents with a mid-systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur and a fourth heart sound. Ventricular septal defect typically presents with a harsh, holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a systolic ejection murmur along the left upper sternal border and a mid-diastolic rumble along the left sternal border, which suggests a possible atrial septal defect. Bicuspid aortic valve would have a systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy would have a harsh systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. Ventricular septal defect would have a harsh holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient comes from a country with a high prevalence of tuberculosis and his father died from tuberculosis, suggesting a possible history of untreated tuberculosis. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a congenital heart defect. Among the options, only atrial septal defect (ASD) presents with a mid-diastolic rumble along the left sternal border and a II systolic ejection murmur along the left upper sternal border. Bicuspid aortic valve presents with a systolic ejection murmur along the right upper sternal border and Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy presents with a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border that can radiate to the neck and Ventricular septal defect presents with a loud holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including exertional dyspnea and cardiac auscultation findings suggest the most likely diagnosis is an atrial septal defect, which causes a blood flow from the left atrium to the right atrium. Bicuspid aortic valve and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy would present with different auscultation findings, while ventricular septal defect would present with a harsh holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest an atrial septal defect (ASD). The presence of a systolic ejection murmur along the left upper sternal border and a mid-diastolic rumble along the left sternal border point towards ASD as well. The lack of changes in the splitting of S2 with inspiration suggests that the cause of the murmur is not pulmonic stenosis. Bicuspid aortic valve and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy would present with different symptoms and physical exam findings. Ventricular septal defect would present with a holosystolic murmur along the left sternal border.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a systolic ejection murmur along the left upper sternal border suggests a possible atrial septal defect. The mid-diastolic rumble along the left sternal border is consistent with tricuspid regurgitation caused by the increased blood flow through the right ventricle. Bicuspid aortic valve and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy usually present with different types of murmurs, while ventricular septal defect typically presents with a holosystolic murmur. Further testing, such as an echocardiogram, would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a systolic ejection murmur and a mid-diastolic rumble, which suggest an atrial septal defect. Bicuspid aortic valve and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy usually have a systolic ejection murmur only. Ventricular septal defect usually has a harsh holosystolic murmur. The family history of tuberculosis and unknown vaccination history also suggest the possibility of infectious diseases.
